attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was conducted on February 27, 2025, to validate the accuracy of stock records by comparing the actual inventory levels with the data in the SAP system. Furthermore, the count evaluated the efficiency of internal controls in managing inventory.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following discrepancies:

Ø  Bread stock showed a shortfall  of -1 Loaf,

Ø  Packing material had  a surplus of +1,259 pieces,

Ø  White flour had a deficit of -2 kg,

Ø  Utto experienced a variance of -1 units,

Ø  Other material items had minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the findings:

Implications:

Although the variances between physical stock and SAP system balances for most inventory items are minimal, indicating that existing controls are generally effective, the significant surplus in packing materials suggests potential recording errors. This may be due to certain polybag packages containing extra pieces.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should strengthen inventory control measures to correct the identified variances and enhance stock accuracy.

·       Additionally, to maintain accurate inventory records, close monitoring and stricter control measures should be implemented to minimize discrepancies.
attributes.remediation_plan: Strengthen inventory controls, conduct regular reconciliations and improve monitoring to minimize discrepancies.

value:
• The surplus in polybags may be influenced by variations in packaging gauge.

  • While existing controls are generally effective, we will maintain them and seek further improvements to minimize or eliminate variances.

•   This may have been influenced by the gauge. We are following up to determine the main cause so we can minimize the impact and maintain our stock levels.

  • We will do our best to maintain the current trend for bread stocks and other materials.

·       In the prior Audit, dated 30th January 2025,the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a shortfall of -51.75 Pieces,

ü  Polybags had +1190 pieces,

ü  White flour had +0.103 Kgs,

White ingredients, Yeast, and utto had immaterial Variances.

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
·       On February 27, 2025, we conducted spot checks on the weight of packed bread prepared for dispatch to verify compliance with the required weight standards before distribution to the market.

·       From the analysis of bread weight, cases of underweight, overweight were noted as illustrated in the table below.

Implications:

·       The presence of underweight bread in the market may lead to non-compliance with weights and measures regulations, exposing the company to potential fines and legal consequences.

Delivering underweight products can result in customer dissatisfaction, damaging the brand’s reputation and potentially leading to loss of market share.
attributes.recommendation: While weight controls are effective in many cases, variations in adherence to weight standards suggest a need for stricter enforcement to maintain consistency and product quality.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To ensure all bread varieties comply with the required weight standards, reducing instances of underweight and overweight products, thereby maintaining regulatory compliance and customer satisfaction by

  • Enforce strict weight control measures at the production level.
  • Conduct regular calibration of weighing machines.
  • Increase spot checks on packed bread before dispatch.

value:
• The observed weights largely fall within the acceptable range.

  • While existing controls will be maintained, we will also conduct regular spot checks and supervision to ensure that all bread varieties comply with the required weight standards.

·       The existing weights standards will be strictly observed.

·       We will also enforce strict measures and conduct random checks.

·       In the prior audit dated 30th January 2025, it was noted that, Underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g CTW -16%,

ü  800 CTW-7%,

ü  400g Long-13%,

ü  200 g Minibread-100%,

ü  600g White bread-10%.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
a)     Production and Market Damages.

·       We reviewed the damages for the period from January 28, 2025, to February 27, 2025, to assess whether there were any instances of damages exceeding the established standard limits of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       From our analysis the production damages were 0.19% of the total production, market damages were 0.54% of the total sales with a cost implication of Kshs 7,911.71 as illustrated in the summary below:

·       The findings were as detailed below:

Implications

·       The production-related damages (0.19%) were within the acceptable threshold (0.20%), indicating effective quality control in the production process. However, continuous monitoring is essential to maintain this standard.

·       Market-related damages slightly exceeded the acceptable limit leading to a cost implication of Kshs 7,911.71. This suggests potential issues that need to be addressed to prevent further losses.

b)     Damage Sent to Ingredient Department.

·       An analysis of damages sent to the ingredient department from January 28, 2025, to February 27, 2025, was conducted. The purpose of this analysis was to verify whether all reported damages at the branch were accurately recorded and to ensure that the physically weighed damages aligned with the expected values based on the analysis.

·        From our analysis, damages sent to ingredient department for the period had a variance of -17.35 Kgs equivalent to -43.37 fewer pieces sent to ingredients’ store. This was as illustrated below:

Implications:

Sending fewer damages to the ingredient department than expected resulted in an unaccounted shortfall in materials, leading to increased cost by Kshs 2,298.87.
attributes.recommendation:
·       To adhere to the set quality control parameters within the production process to minimize damages.

·       Bread production should be aligned with actual sales demand to prevent overproduction and reduce market damages.

Branch management should ensure production equipment and ovens are regularly inspected and maintained to prevent unnecessary damages caused by malfunctions.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Market damages exceeded the acceptable limit, leading to losses.
Remediation Plan:

  • Align production with actual sales demand to prevent overproduction.
  • Strengthen sales forecasting models to minimize market damages.

value:
·       The existing controls are effective and will be maintained while ensuring the production of high-quality bread.

·       Additionally, efforts will be made to further minimize damages to even lower levels.

·       Market damages are primarily caused by high temperatures, leading to bread expiring before its due date.

·       To mitigate this, production will be aligned with sales demand to minimize losses.

·       The sales crew will be instructed to place orders based on customer demand.

·       We will also ensure that our final product maintains high quality while making additional efforts to minimize damages.

·       Furthermore, the high temperatures in the region are causing products to expire before their due date.

·       To address this, we will align production more closely with sales demand and do our best to manage bread stock effectively.

·       During the prior audit dated 30th January 2025, it was noted it was found that;        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.19% of the production.

Market damages stood at 0.44% of the sales.

attributes.title: Minishop Spot Check
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the mini shop on February 28, 2025, to assess whether operations were being carried out in line with the established standards.

·       The bread balance at the mini shop was subtracted from the total loadings for the day to determine the daily sales, and to establish whether the expected sales figure aligned with the confirmed amount recorded in the Mpesa till.

·       The audit findings confirmed that mini shop operations complied with set standards, and reconciliation procedures were appropriately followed to ensure alignment between stock transfers and sales.

·       The table below illustrates the findings.

Implications:

The accurate reconciliation of sales and stock transfers at the mini shop indicates that controls over daily sales transactions are effective.
attributes.recommendation: The current controls in the mini shop are working effectively and should be sustained, with improvements implemented where necessary.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve adherence to the Bill of Materials (BOM) and optimize production efficiency, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Strict Adherence to BOM: Ensure that raw material measurements align with the established BOM to maintain consistency in product quality.

  2. Regular Review of Mixing Charts: Conduct frequent reviews and cross-checks of mixing chart entries to detect errors or inconsistencies.

  3. Audit Follow-ups: Conduct regular audits to verify adherence to BOM and implement necessary corrective actions to improve efficiency.

value: We will continue to uphold controls at the mini shop.
We will continue to uphold controls in place.

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balance as at 27 February 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       The outstanding debt exclusive of prepayments was KES 616,987.25 as detailed in Appendix II below:

Implications:

If unsecured balances remain unpaid, they could negatively impact liquidity and operational efficiency.
attributes.recommendation:
• Sales representative is encouraged to actively follow up on overdue balances, particularly unsecured debts, to prevent them from becoming bad debts.

  • An engagement with clients who has outstanding balances is necessary to establish firm repayment commitments.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve debt management and enhance financial control, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Strict Credit Control Policies: Enforce tighter credit policies to minimize the risk of overdue and bad debts.

  2. Regular Debtor Follow-ups: Implement routine follow-ups on outstanding balances to ensure timely collections.

value: ·       We are currently adhering to the policy of supplying bread to clients who have sufficient security deposits, extra Cent and Supa Points.
Sales team are following all outs standing debts.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was assessed over a 31day period, from January 28, 2025, to February 27, 2025 with the goal of determining whether the hired production workers were meeting the set efficiency target of 4.50 bags.

·       The analysis revealed that the actual production efficiency was 4.45 bags per worker, which was slightly below the set target.

·       The review also identified that five additional workers were hired beyond the required number, leading to an extra cost of Kshs 5,433.

·       A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Implications:

The discrepancy between expected and actual production suggests opportunities for refining workforce allocation to optimize productivity without incurring extra costs.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The branch management is advised to align workforce hiring with actual production needs to prevent unnecessary labour costs.

·       A review of production workflows is recommended to eliminate bottlenecks that may be affecting worker productivity.
attributes.effect: The discrepancy between expected and actual production suggests opportunities for refining workforce allocation to optimize productivity without incurring extra costs.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve production efficiency and optimize resource utilization, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Workforce Optimization: Align staffing levels with actual production needs to minimize unnecessary labor costs.

  2. Performance Monitoring: Track production efficiency metrics regularly and implement corrective actions when targets are not met.

  3. Equipment Maintenance: Conduct routine maintenance and timely repairs to prevent equipment breakdowns that impact productivity.

value:
·       The shift cuts during the period were due to generator maintenance and oven services, which impacted production efficiency.

We will implement preventive measures in collaboration with KAF to mitigate future disruptions.
Lack of efficiency attainment was mostly contributed by machines breakdown and maintenance; we will align to ensure we archive our targets and efficiency.

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage and Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The audit aimed to evaluate the fuel consumption of the branch's sales vehicles for the period from February 1 to February 28, 2025.

·       The primary objectives were to assess compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any inefficiencies and propose recommendations to optimize fuel usage and reduce associated costs.

Findings revealed that fuel consumption at the branch generally adhered to the set standards. However, TukTuk KTWC 874X did not record any fuel consumption during the period due to mechanical breakdowns, as detailed in Appendix I.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure timely maintenance and repairs of vehicles to prevent extended breakdown periods, minimizing operational inefficiencies.

value: We will continue to uphold controls in regards to fuel utilization per vehicle.
We will continue to uphold controls in regards to fuel utilization.
In the prior audit, it was noted that fuel consumption at the branch was within the set standards, except Kabata route, Kyuso route and Nguni route.
